my more controversial take is I LOVE and support ROM hackers and modders & feel strongly that they are legit game devs who deserve hella props for dedication to their craft but i know this one is kind of fiddly

like there's companies like bethesda who also love their modders and will even hire from their modder pool, but then companies like nintendo who despise them üò´

content.html:
Some assholes worshipping a sun god from down south just put up a fort, saying this is the edge of civilization.

They are harrying the lizard-folk in the swamp and have killed a bunch of the cave clans. The delicate peace everyone has worked hard to achieve is falling apart.

They're saying that you all are bandits, sworn to chaos and need to be killed. They've put prices on your heads.

Inspired by: https://www.prismaticwasteland.com/blog/the-keep-on-the-borderlands-is-full-of-lies

#KeepOnTheBorderlands #DnD #DungeonsAndDragons #TTRPG

content.html:
üö®üåøGRASS GIF ALERTüåøüö®

In #Techtonica, the grass ~fwooshes~ when you build machines, waves in the cavern breeze, and twirls below the M.O.L.E. (our black hole terrain manipulator).

Not sure we've been this pumped about grass before, but here we are.

content.html:
Traffic is wild out there. ü§£

Up til now, cars would drive in a random direction and every few seconds would turn a random amount. This was chaotic. _This_ is meant to be adding tiles that force the cars to turn corners.

It's not working hahaha. As usual for me though, if it generates good gifs, it's worth pursuing.

#pico8

content.html:
Every few months, I find myself recommending basically everyone read this one article about the protactile deafblind language. But particularly relevant to mastodon users (AND people working on automated image captioning) is its great discussion of what makes good alt text.

There is such a thing as excess detail! It may make you look like a True Ally, but you're not helping blind people. #screenreaders #accessibility

https://audio.mcsweeneys.net/transcripts/against_access.html
content.value: Every few months, I find myself recommending basically everyone read this one article about the protactile deafblind language. But particularly relevant to mastodon users (AND people working on automated image captioning) is its great discussion of what makes good alt text.There is such a thing as excess detail! It may make you look like a True Ally, but you're not helping blind people. #screenreaders #accessibilityhttps://audio.mcsweeneys.net/transcripts/against_access.html

photo.alt:
In recent years, there has been a rush on the internet to supply image descriptions and to call out those who don‚Äôt. This may be an example of community accountability at work, but it‚Äôs striking to observe that those doing the most fierce calling out or correcting are sighted people. Such efforts are largely self-defeating. I cannot count the times I‚Äôve stopped reading a video transcript because it started with a dense word picture. Even if a description is short and well done, I often wish there were no description at all. Get to the point, already! How ironic that striving after access can actually create a barrier. When I pointed this out during one of my seminars, a participant made us all laugh by doing a parody: ‚ÄúMary is wearing a green, blue, and red striped shirt; every fourth stripe also has a purple dot the size of a pea in it, and there are forty-seven stripes‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre killing me,‚Äù I said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt take any more of that!‚Äù

Now serious, she said it was clear to her that none of that stuff about Mary‚Äôs clothes mattered, at least if her clothes weren‚Äôt the point. What mattered most about the image was that Mary was holding her diploma and smiling. ‚ÄúBut,‚Äù she wondered, ‚Äúdo I say, Mary has a huge smile on her face as she shows her diploma or Mary has an exuberant smile or showing her teeth in a smile and her eyes are crinkled at the edges?‚Äù

It‚Äôs simple. Mary has a huge smile on her face is the best one. It‚Äôs the don‚Äôt-second-guess-yourself option. My thinking around this issue is enriched by the philosopher Brian Massumi‚Äôs concept of ‚Äúesqueness.‚Äù He exemplifies it by discussing a kid who plays a tiger:

One look at a tiger, however fleeting and incomplete, whether it be in the zoo or in a book or in a film or video, and presto! the child is tigerized‚Ä¶ The perception itself is a vital gesture. The child immediately sets about, not imitating the tiger‚Äôs substantial form as he saw it, but rather giving it life‚Äîgiving it more life. The child plays the tiger in situations in which the child has never seen a tiger. More than that, it plays the tiger in situations no tiger has ever seen, in which no earthly tiger has ever set paw.
Just as the child and an actual tiger are not one bit alike, the words Mary has a huge smile on her face have nothing in common with the picture of Mary holding her diploma. Yet the tiger announces something to the world, its essence, and a kid can become tiger-ized and be tiger-esque, their every act shouting, I am a tiger. The picture of Mary at her graduation is shouting something, and the words Mary has a huge smile on her face are also shouting something. It is at the level beyond each actuality, in the swirl that each stirs up, that the two meet.

content.html:
Vultures are holy creatures.
Tending the dead.
Bowing low.
Bared head.
Whispers to cold flesh,
‚ÄúYour old name is not your king.
I rename you ‚ÄòEverything.‚Äô‚Äù

(From my poetry collection Field Guide to the Haunted Forest by Jarod K. Anderson.) #poetry
